commit_message:
Run db_sync commands as the proper users

keystone-manage db_sync creates a log file
/var/log/keystone/keystone.log (and other db_sync commands create similar

subject: VM resize: skip ssh work for VMs w/o local disks
commit_message:
VM resize: skip ssh work for VMs w/o local disks

Closes-bug: 1303203

VM resizing action is a bit fragile because of its dependency on
nova-compute user being able to freely ssh/scp among compute hosts.
Resize will fail under two scnearios:
- when SSH keys are not set up properly
- when SSH dest must be a full hostname (say kerberos is used for
  authentication) - currently only remote IPs are used for ssh/scp.

Instead of fully fixing this problem, this commit tries to mitigate
the reliance on ssh/scp in a legitimate scenario in which no ssh/scp
interactions are needed -- when a resized VM has no local disk,
thus disk_info being an empty list. In this scenario, the VM in
question only has volumes attached, which voids the need of copying
disk images around.

One existing test case is modified to avoid triggering the new code. One
test case is added to ensure the new code is properly triggered when VM
has no local disk.

subject: cinder client should retry with Retry-After value
commit_message:
cinder client should retry with Retry-After value

If a request fails but the response contains a "Retry-After",
the cinder client should wait the amount of time and then retry

Cinder client should report a warning to user and continue with retry,
so that user can cancel the operation if not interested in retry

The value in "Retry-After" header will be in seconds or GMT value,
client should handle both the cases

How many times client should retry will be controlled by user through
"--retries" argument to cinder api
example, cinder --retries 3 availability-zone-list
If request was not sucessful within the retries, client should raise
the exception

Added test case "test_rate_limit_overlimit_exception" in which client
raises the exception when request was not succesful within the retries
after wainting for "Retry-After" time

Added test case "test_rate_limit" in which client succesfully retries
the request after wainting for "Retry-After" time

Present limitation - client will wait with the seconds given
by the server.Now a warning message will be reported to the user
with this waiting time, user can cancel the retry if he thinks that
this will be huge time.

In future implementation, user can set max wait time for "Retry-After"
as a command line option or a configuration option. Then client should
retry only if the "retry-After" value is less than what the user has set

commit_message:
Change report_interval from 4 to 30, agent_down_time from 9 to 75

report_interval is how often an agent sends out a heartbeat to the
service. The Neutron service responds to these 'report_state' RPC
messages by updating the agent's heartbeat DB record.
The last heartbeat is then compared to the configured
agent_down_time to determine if the agent is up or down.
The agent's status is used when scheduling networks on DHCP
and L3 agents.

In the spirit of sane defaults suited for production, these values
should be bumped to reduce the load on the Neutron service
dramatically, freeing up CPU time to perform intensive operations.

subject: Make network_cache more robust with neutron
commit_message:
Make network_cache more robust with neutron

Currently, nova treats neutron as the source of truth for which ports are
attached to an instance which is a false assumption. Because of this
if someone creates a port in neutron with a device_id that matches one
of their existing instance_ids that port will eventually show up in
nova list (through the periodic heal task).

This problem usually manifests it's self when nova-compute
calls to neutron to create a port and the request times out (though
the port is actually created in neutron). When this occurs the instance
can be rescheduled on another compute node which it will call out to
neutron again to create a port. In this case two ports will show
up in the network_cache table (since they have the same instance_id) though
only one port is attached to the instance.

This patch addresses this issue by only adding ports to network_cache
if nova successfully allocated the port (or it was passed in). This
way these ghost ports are avoided. A follow up patch will come later
that garbage collects these ports.

Closes-bug: #1258620
Closes-bug: #1272195

	nova/network/neutronv2/api.py

Prior to the (sync|async)_command decorators, extension methods had to
construct command results themselves, which required that they have
the name of the command being executed.

When the async_command decorator was introduced, we wanted to maintain
the current command interface, so that a command could be made

this objective, without requiring decorated methods to accept a
command_name. This patch modifies both decorators to no longer pass
the command_name argument, and modifies existing command methods not

subject: Rationalize get_resources for mongodb
commit_message:
Rationalize get_resources for mongodb

Fixes bug 1288372

Previously the performance of the /v2/resources API without
constraints degraded sharply as the size of the meter collection
grows, regardless of the number of known resources.

We rationalize the underpinning storage driver method for mongo
so as to rebase the query on the much smaller resource collection.

This requires a subtle change in the semantic of the first and
last sample timestamps which decorate the resource representation.
These values are now defined respectively as being not later than
youngest sample, and not earlier than the oldest timestamp, known
for each resource.

In order to maintain support for "tight" timestamp constraints
on resource queries, we adopt a hybrid approach. For resource
queries without timestamp constraints, we optimize with a simple
query on the resource collection, but revert to a map-reduce on
the meter collection for timestamp-constrained queries.

The logic being that when one makes a resources query constrained
by timestamp, one is essentially asking a question about samples,
hence prepared to incur the cost of a query on the meter collection.
Whereas for other constraints (user_id, project_id, source etc.)
on the resources queries, one is more asking a question purely
related to the resources themselves.

(cherry picked from commit 7b4d4d44650bbe10225084b3ab5155f70ebebb95)

Check for silent failure of tgtadm remove

In order to work around a failure to remove targets that
had a reconnect the force flag was added to the tgt delete cmd.

It turns out there's a bug in tgt where some versions will
sometimes silently fail when using the force flag.
    (https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/tgt/+bug/1305343)

The problem is that in the gates since we merged the force change
there's a very high number of cases where lvremove fails because
the device is still active.  It appears that this is a result of
the silent force failures in target.

This patch adds a simple check after the force target removal,
if it detects the target is still present it reverts back to the old
non-force method to catch the cases that don't actually need the
force option.

This is a work-around until the version of target in the distros
is updated and can be used reliably, but closes the gate issue
bug that was reported.

all of the provided volumes path in a single lvremove command,
while retrying it several times.
This is causing the command to fail, when the deleted volumes
are reappearing in the next iteration of the retry loop.

and raising an exception for volumes which failed to be removed.

subject: correctly use auth_url for keystone client
commit_message:
correctly use auth_url for keystone client

We are misusing argument auth_url and endpoint argument for keystone
client. Keystone client uses endpoint(35357 by default) to access to
keystone service and this endpoint is got from catalogs via POST request
against /tokens. The port 5000 api port 35537 api(service API and admin
API in document) both respond this POST /tokens request. In another
word, both APIs could be used as auth url but only 35357 one could be
used for accessing services.

We misused auth url value from environment and passed it into endpoint
argument in keystone client which caused our APIs doesn't work when
users set their auth url as 5000 one.

This patch pass that AUTH_URL value into auth_url in keystone client and
keystone codes could get the correct endpoint url(management url) in its
codes which could help Rally support both 5000 one and 35357 one as auth
url. Also removing _change_port could solve some DNS issues and
non-default auth url port.

Close-bug #1306448
Close-bug #1285262
Close-bug #1305679
